comments.commentBody: There are a lot of other benefits beyond taxi availability. Perhaps you've never used one... you know exactly where they are when you select them, they come right to you with a very precise estimated wait time, and they call when they arrive. Normal cabs give you a ten minute estimate and may or may not show up, may or may not actually get there in 2 to 4 times the amount of time. Ubers also tend to be much cleaner, if you're into that kind of thing. If regulated taxis operated like this, Uber would not be necessary. They would not be more expensive.

Uber is a business and market experiment. Using supply / demand / pricing in a different way often comes with this kind of experiment. Scheduled airlines have very different prices for essentially the same service - transportation from A to B on a certain day. Passengers moan and groan. Some take Amtrak instead (which also has time of day pricing) Articles are written, studies are done, and "yield management" pricing continues to be refined. As with Uber, cabs and public transportation options in large cities, options fortunately exist in nearly all cases ... Getting around Manhattan or DC in the rain or snow will always be subject to either capacity constraints, price premiums or both. This seems an area where lightly regulated free market interplay between buyers and sellers will work its way out. And give reporters and columnists something to write about in the meantime.

You can debate whether Uber is a taxi service or not, from the perspective of Uber as a business. However, for the consumer, functionally it's the same as a taxi service. A taxi service which lacks the benefits of regulation, and which by competing with regular taxis will reduce their availability.

So what is the benefit of Uber to consumers? More taxi availability? Regulation defines the number of taxi licenses, it's not a real problem. Cheaper prices? Not with surge pricing. I think in the long term Uber is bad for consumers, and will be until and unless it is regulated like taxis are.

Jonathan Kuhn, the NYC Parks director of art and antiquities, responded:

A bicycle ride to the 23rd Street and 2nd Avenue address in question could not locate the tree marker in question. While street trees are within the jurisdiction of the Parks Department, sidewalks and any plaques set within them are not, and are the property of the building owners. Tree markers are generally a vexing problem in terms of documentation, as many have been placed semi-officially, and undergone little or no process of review or permanent documentation.

An occupational hazard is that the certain sturdy plaques may long outlast the trees, as does a plaque placed in the pavement at the east side of Madison Avenue between 60th and 61st Street in 1960 by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation that acknowledges 100 trees in the vicinity planted in honor of Mayor Wagner. There are no trees on this particular block, though the Million Trees campaign has made significant strides in restoring the urban forest citywide.

There is a concrete plaque, almost like a foot stone, on 2nd avenue just slightly south of 23rd (west side) noting that Mayor Abraham Beame planted "this tree" and it was one of ... and the number is not clear, but I think 700.  This poor plaque seems quite forgotten by time and I wonder why the tree planting was considered "plaque-able" at the time.
In Central Park, at least, they turn them off in the winter to avoid frozen pipes.

Henry Hale Bliss (June 13, 1830 – September 14, 1899) was the first person killed by a motor vehicle accident in the United States, and the first known in the Americas.[1] On September 13, 1899 he was disembarking from a streetcar at West 74th Street and Central Park West in New York City, when an electric-powered taxicab (Automobile No. 43)… .

Jonathan Kuhn, the NYC Parks director of art and antiquities, replied:

One might call this a "half Gaynor" (diving pun) as its central image is a bust.

As with 98% of Parks' monuments, this one was commissioned by private citizens, who raised $23,600 (more than $300,000 in today's dollars). German-born sculptor Adolph Alexander Weinman sculpted the bust flanked by a pair of allegorical bas-reliefs representing Law and Strength on one side and Knowledge and Ease on the other. The granite stele and sculptural group, located at the northernmost portion of Cadman Plaza, was dedicated in 1926.

Like our current New York mayor, Gaynor was a Brooklyn resident. He was a journalist, lawyer, state supreme court justice and served as
Mayor of New York from 1910 to 1913. His Parks Commissioner, Charles Stover, was an early playground advocate and greatly expanded recreational opportunities.

The monument's inscription refers to Gaynor as a “defender of civil liberties”, and ends with “Ours is a government of laws not men” — alluding to Gaynor’s independent stance. Although supported by Tammany Hall political machine, Gaynor assembled a pro-reform government, that cost him politically. The target of an assassination attempt in 1910, Gaynor died while running for reelection in 1913 on a reform ticket.

Weinman also modeled sculptural ornament for the Prison Ship Martyrs Monument in Fort Greene Park, a bust of John Purroy Mitchel in Central Park, and Civic Fame atop the Municipal Building.

The major problem with this argument you could just as easily say that people are buying Hybrids because they are more cost efficient, especially if you have long commutes.  I still think we need more data to be conclusive.

10% *is* often considering the large number of purchases, and $750 *is* enough of a deduction for people, especially business owners with several vehicles, to jump on.

Furthermore, typically as assets depreciate, they are replaced.

My issue with George Will's statement is that he's pointing to what is largely a business sector purchase, then making claims about consumer choices as a whole. And it ignores the rise in demand, along with greater choices and lower prices, for hybrids, and the keen interest in electric cars despite their being priced at bleeding-edge levels.

It's a multifaceted story. G. Will took pieces of it, to try and prove a general point.

If "$750 *is* enough of a deduction for people, especially business owners with several vehicles, to jump on. " then the next incremental $1,400+ that you get buying hybrids would be more than enough for businesses to switch over from buying trucks to buying hybrids. But it is not.
